QUOTE OF THE DAY“There are two motives for 
      reading a book: one, that you enjoy it; the other, that you can boast 
      about it.” - Bertrand Russell 



DID YOU KNOW?An albatross can sleep while it 
      flies. It apparently dozes while cruising at 25 mph. 



TONIGHT ON THE CBS 
      EVENING NEWSHere is an early preview of what we 
      are planning for tonight’s CBS EVENING NEWS from Anchor and Managing 
      Editor, Katie Couric… Hi everyone, After the town 
      of Greensburg, Kansas, was reduced to little more than rubble over the 
      weekend, a survivor was found in the wreckage today – bringing some good 
      news to the grim story. Hari Sreenivasan will have our report on 
      the aftermath from Greensburg. When a disaster like this massive 
      tornado strikes, the National Guard is often called upon to help citizens 
      piece together broken lives. But during wartime, the guard isn’t always 
      there in full force, David Martin will report. Reports said 
      the tornado was more than a mile wide and it was a whopping F-5 storm – 
      the classification for the very strongest twisters. What’s behind such a 
      monster tornado? Cynthia Bowers will have the story from a storm 
      prediction center in Norman, Oklahoma. In business news, prices at 
      the gas pump surged over the weekend, reaching $4.00 per gallon in some 
      places. Anthony Mason will have the reasons behind the pump price 
      spike. Yesterday French voters elected Nicholas Sarkozy, the 
      pro-American conservative candidate, in a close election that had a huge 
      turnout. But would the French candidates’ personal lives horrify American 
      voters? Jeff Greenfield will take a look at what American voters 
      can learn from some of the culture behind France’s election. And 
      correspondent John Blackstone reports on what some are calling an 
      agricultural emergency in the United States: the sudden disappearance of 
      honeybees. The die-off has hit 27 states – and with about 30 percent of 
      the nation’s food supply being pollinated by bees, the risk is great and 
      scientists are scrambling to nail down the cause. We’ll have the story in 
      a segment we’re calling Saving the World. Finally, it was a 
      day of much pomp and fanfare at the White House, as Queen Elizabeth II was 
      welcomed to Washington. President Bush tonight is hosting the first 
      white-tie dinner of his presidency in honor of the queen. Mark 
      Phillips will share details of Elizabeth’s elegant day inside the 
      beltway. I hope you’ll join us. Katie For more 
      information on these stories, please click on the following links:
Survivor Found In Kansas Tornado Rubble Click 
      Here A White House Welcome For Queen Elizabeth Click 
      Here And here's a look at one of the stories we’re working 
      on for Tuesday's broadcast: Murderers sentenced to death. But 
      find out why the state can't pull the switch. That story and MUCH more 
      Tuesday on the CBS EVENING NEWS. If you would like 
      more information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on 
      the following address and e-mail us: evening@cbsnews.com 



TONIGHT ON DAVID 
      LETTERMANDave sits down with talk show host and friend 
      Regis Philbin! And, a spectacular musical performance by Darlene Love! 
      



TUESDAY MORNING ON THE 
      EARLY SHOWHannah Storm, Julie 
      Chen, Russ Mitchell and Chris Wragge, of our New York 
      affiliate WCBS, anchor THE EARLY SHOW 
      from New York. Dave Price will bring us the weather. Harry 
      Smith is on assignment. Along with the top news of the day, 
      we will also have the following stories: CONSUMERWATCH: 
      RATING DIETS: If you're anxious about fitting into that bathing suit 
      this summer, you're not alone. Right now, nearly half of all Americans are 
      on a diet--with the average person wanting to lose more than 30 pounds! So 
      what's the best way to do it? Consumer Reports magazine has done 
      the homework for you--revealing which diets get the best results. 
      EARLY SHOW Consumer Correspondent 
      Susan Koeppen will join us with important new information about 
      diet plans. 
 
TAKE LOU: GAS PRICES: In his weekly 
      commentary, Lou Dobbs, anchor and managing editor of CNN’s Lou Dobbs 
      Tonight, will join us to talk about gas prices. 
SIMPLE SOLUTIONS: DRUG STORE DEALS: Walk down an 
      aisle at your local drugstore and it's easy to get overwhelmed by the 
      hundreds of beauty products you can choose from. So the editors at Real 
      Simple magazine compiled a list of the best drugstore skincare and 
      hair products to save you time and money the next time you're shopping. 
      Kris Connell from Real Simple magazine will join us with some of 
      her favorites. CSI WEEK: CSI MIAMI BEHIND THE SCENES: 
      Tuesday morning, we continue CSI week. Monday night's CSI: 
      Miami has your standard dose of stylized murder and intrigue in an 
      exotic setting. What it also has is Horatio being Horatio. To the delight 
      of millions of fans, each week actor David Caruso puts his stamp on what 
      has become one of television's most iconic characters. We'll take a look 
      behind the scenes of the hit show. MOTHER'S DAY GIFTS: 
      Don't know what to get mom this Mother's day? Style expert Sarah Shirley 
      will join us with some gift suggestions that may be the perfect way for 
      you to thank mom for all she does. DENNIS HAYSBERT ON THE 
      UNIT: Dennis Haysbert is best known to television audiences for his 
      portrayal of President David Palmer on the series 24, for which he 
      received his first Golden Globe nomination. Now, he stars as Jonas Blane 
      on The Unit, one of CBS's biggest hits. The Unit offers a 
      realistic look at a group of elite special forces fighting terrorism in 
      all corners of the world. Tuesday night's cliff hanger season finale will 
      show you what the buzz is about, when The Unit, led by Haysbert's 
      character, face criminal charges that threaten it's very existence. We'll 
      speak with Haysbert Tuesday morning. YOUNG AT HEART: HOT 
      GRANNY: Grandmothers aren't what they used to be. "Hot" and 
      "grandmother" are not two words you usually think of together, but 
      gerontologist Mel Walsh's new book, Hot Granny, says otherwise. 
      Walsh's book defines what exactly makes a grandmother sizzle. How you can 
      accept the limitations brought on by age and learn to reinvent yourself? 
      Hot Granny is filled with practical advice on how to be happy, 
      healthy and sexy into your golden years. Tuesday morning, Walsh will join 
      us with tips you won't want to miss. If you would like more 
      information on any of these stories or the broadcast, please click on the 
      following address and e-mail us: earlyshow@cbs.com
